com.pb.sawdust.tabledata

Class LongDataColumn

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pb.sawdust.tabledata.LongDataColumn
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    DataColumn<java.lang.Long>, java.lang.Iterable<java.lang.Long>

    public class LongDataColumn
extends java.lang.Object
implements DataColumn<java.lang.Long>
    The LongDataColumn provides a wrapper class for DataColumns of the type DataType.LONG. Being a wrapper class, its sole constructor takes a DataColumn<Long> instance as an argument, and all of its DataColumn interface methods just delegate to that "wrapped" column's methods. Because the (generic) type of the DataColumn<T> interface implementation is explicitly stated in this class' signature, it offers method calls without the need for casting. As an example, look at the following class defnition: 
         class Foo {
         public DataColumn getLongDataColumn() {
             ...
         }
     }
    Because of erasure, any call to getLongDataColumn() will, from the compiler's perspective, return a DataColumn instance, not a DataColumn<Long> instance. That is, to get access to the <Long> type parameter, a cast is required: 
         Foo foo = new Foo();
     DataColumn column = (DataColumn) foo.getLongDataColumn();
    This cast seems redundant and is rather annoying. If it was not done, then any call to DataColumn methods would not have access to the specified type parameter (without a cast): 
         DataColumn column = foo.getLongDataColumn();
     Long[] columnData = (Long[]) column.getData();
    Again, an annoying cast. However, by specifying the generic type in the class defninition, as done with this class, such a cast is not necessary: 
         class Foo {
         public LongDataColumn getLongDataColumn() {
             ...
         }
     }
     ...
     DataColumn column = foo.getLongDataColumn();
     Long[] columnData = column.getData();
    Preferably, the second to last line above could be written as: 
         LongDataColumn column = foo.getLongDataColumn();
    Thus, the casts are removed with little programming hassle (the addition of a wrapper constructor).

      • getCellByKey

        public java.lang.Long getCellByKey(java.lang.Object key)
        Description copied from interface: DataColumn
        Get the column value at a specified key location. This method is optional and requires some sort of access to the primary key of the source data set. Whether the primary key is dynamic (i.e. changing the key on the data table will cause this method to refer to the new key) is implemntation specific.
        Specified by:
        getCellByKey in interface DataColumn<java.lang.Long>
        Parameters:

        Returns:
